name: Count Univalue Subtrees
title: Count Univalue Subtrees
content:
Given the root of a binary tree, return the number of uni-value subtrees.

A uni-value subtree means all nodes of the subtree have the same value.

 

Example 1:

Input: root = [5,1,5,5,5,null,5]
Output: 4

Example 2:

Input: root = []
Output: 0

Example 3:

Input: root = [5,5,5,5,5,null,5]
Output: 6

 

Constraints:

  • The number of the node in the tree will be in the range [0, 1000].
  • -1000 <= Node.val <= 1000

discussion_posts.name: guestly
discussion_posts.content: Why is `[5,1,5,5,5,null,5]` produce 4? There are obviously 5 `5` nodes in this tree?

discussion_posts.name: bloomer
discussion_posts.content: Its not consistent with the example provided to count subtrees.\nif this tree [5,1,5,5,5,null,5] is 4 counts,\nthen [5, 1 , 5] should be 1 and not 2.

discussion_posts.name: swanseafc
discussion_posts.content:
This is a bad question, due to the recursive definition of a subtree. You're really going to have to count all leaf nodes, since a single node is by definition a tree as well. Also, the two right (5) nodes from coming down from the root node should actually count as 3 subtrees; there are two separate subtrees of single 5 nodes and then another subtree of two nodes, both with value 5. This question shouldn't have been asked.
  ```
     5
   /    \
  1        5
 / \          \
5   5          5

```

discussion_posts.content: For those who struggle with understanding this (ill-worded) question: a uni-val subtree needs to have ALL its descendants with the same value.\nIf one descendant is different, the whole tree does not count.
